Award.AwardTitle: Gamma-Ray Astronomy and Cosmic-ray Astrophysics with the VERITAS and HAWC Observatories (University of Utah Group)
Award.AbstractNarration:
Gamma-rays are the highest energy form of electromagnetic radiation. Observations of astrophysical gamma-rays serve as probes of physical conditions and processes in the most extreme environments throughout the Universe, and can be used to test fundamental physics. This award supports scientists at the University of Utah to carry out gamma-ray astrophysics research using two complementary ground-based observatories. The Very Energetic Radiation Imaging Telescope Array System (VERITAS), located in southern Arizona, is designed to study high energy gamma-rays with very sensitive pointed observations. The High Altitude Water Cherenkov (HAWC) observatory, located on the slopes of the Sierra Negra in Mexico, is a continuously-operating array with a wide field of view that can observe two-thirds of the high energy gamma-ray sky every day. The University of Utah group will contribute to the operation and maintenance of VERITAS and HAWC and work on analysis and interpretation of the scientific data. The group will continue and expand their existing education and outreach activities using the on-campus South Physics Observatory, the high altitude Willard L. Eccles Observatory, and the Star Base Utah Observatory for both public education and student projects. They will build new connections to Utah senior citizens through courses developed for the University's Osher Institute.

The University of Utah group will use VERITAS to extend detections of flaring active galactic nuclei to higher redshifts, setting more stringent limits on the flux of extragalactic background light. Long-term VERITAS observations of high mass x-ray binaries as well as other galactic binaries and microquasars will be used to explore similarities in their time-dependent gamma-ray emission, while observations of Galactic supernova remnants will be used to explore the origin of galactic cosmic rays. Using both VERITAS and HAWC synergistically, the group will explore the origin of cosmic rays in diffuse supernova remnants and pulsar wind nebulae, and enhance the search for neutralino Dark Matter emission from unidentified high galactic latitude VHE gamma-ray sources.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research grant supported astronomical observations of the most energetic objects in the universe - stellar mass black holes, remnants of supernova explosions, compact stars, and high energy cosmic rays- using the VERITAS and HAWC observatories.  This research project discovered a puzzling emission of gamma-rays along the entire orbit of a compact object (black hole or neutron star) in a 28-day orbit around a more massive, white star (LS I +61 303) [Figure 1]. Correlations between the high energy gamma-ray emissions and separately observed X-ray emissions indicated that at least two independent processes are responsible for the energetic emission from this object. We discovered high energy emission from the jets emanating from the binary system SS433. This is the first discovery of particle acceleration from the particle stream jets emanating from a  3-10 solar mass black hole[Figure 2]. 


This grant supported the creation of the 2HWC survey of high energy gamma-ray sources over the entire northern hemisphere sky. This grant supported subsequent follow-up observations of the catalog of 2HWC sources list using the higher resolution VERITAS and FERMI observatories.  The resulting join FERMI-VERITAS-HAWC catalog uncovered a new population of gamma-ray emitting objects whose peak emission at the highest energies, making them difficult to detect by the VERITAS and Fermi observatories.


This research project also discovered a population of high energy particles (called muons)  which are created by cosmic rays, and which are traveling horizontal paths across the atmosphere [Figure 3]. These particles are serendipitously observed in the HAWC observatory, and they provide a limiting background for the use of HAWC as a detector of high energy astrophysical neutrinos from astrophysical sources.

This research project developed a computational framework  (3ML) for the simultaneous analysis of observations from a satellite observatory (Fermi), a ground-based optical observatory of gamma-rays (VERITAS), and a mountain altitude particle detector of gamma rays (HAWC). The 3ML framework was used for extending the scientific analysis of all three observatories, and also for providing the inter-calibration between the observatories.  

The research project supported faculty researchers, postdoctoral researchers, graduate students, and undergraduate students to perform the astronomical observations with VERITAS and HAWC. These participants also assisted in the design construction and commissioning of a new 9.8-meter diameter  "Schwarzschild-Couder Telescope" (SCT) at the FL Whipple Observatory [Figure 4].  The SCT is a third generation optical telescope for gamma-ray astronomy, providing a wide field of view and employing a state-of-the-art "high-speed silicon photomultiplier" camera. 

The research project supported graduate students and faculty to develop new astronomical instrumentation that uses a quantum property of light called `photon bunching'. Photons, or particles of light, will bunch together in space and time due to the quantum "spin"  property of the light particle. This bunch effect can only be observed using high-speed digitizers which can continuously record the arrival time (250 million observations per second) of the stream of light particles from distant stars. This grant supported the world?s first demonstration of photon bunching in the laboratory and from two bright stars using a high-speed digitizer and a high-speed software correlator for calculating the photon bunching the following day. The observation of photon bunching in the twin 3-m StarBase telescopes is a breakthrough demonstrator of the success of this technique [Figure 5], and the resulting technology is now being deployed on the VERITAS telescopes. The VERITAS telescopes have a possibility of reconstructing images of nearby stars in visible light with ultra-high resolution using the photon bunching properties of light.


This research project supported broader impacts of research which benefit the development of a trained STEM workforce through graduate and postdoctoral student training. Faculty and student supported by this grant also led multiple outreach activities, including hosting public star parties at the South Physics Observatory, working with visiting summer students on selected research projects, and mentoring local high school students on FIRST Robotics Team 3006. The faculty and students of this research project also organized the 2018 meeting of the Four Corners Section of the American Physical Society, at the University of Utah. This 2-day research symposium brought more than 250 faculty and students together to present the results of their research, and to gain training in new diversity initiatives for underrepresented minorities in Physics and Astronomy. 

An additional broader impact of the research project was the founding of the Consortium for Dark Sky Studies. The Consortium for Dark Sky Studies (CDSS, http://darkskystudies.org/, D. Kieda, Co-Director) is dedicated to the study of the effects of dark skies and artificial lighting on astronomical observations, microclimate environment, bird migration patterns, human health, air pollution as well as economic impacts. During November 12-14, 2018, CDSS hosted the 2018 international Artificial Light at Night Conference (ALAN 2018). More than 100 researchers participated from countries across the world[Figure 6]. You can find  the conference program at  http://artificiallightatnight.weebly.com/uploads/3/7/0/5/37053463/alan_2018_booklet.pdf
